title: Phase 1: Core Substrate
description:
Build the foundational substrate for GBE.

## Deliverables
- gbe-router: Message broker for routing between components
- gbe-adapter: Universal wrapper for any Unix command
- gbe-buffer: Storage layer (rope for files, ring for streams)
- gbe-client: Terminal UI with ratatui
- Protocol: Message definitions and serialization
- Text interface: Bash-like shell experience

## Success Criteria
- Can wrap any Unix command via adapter
- Message passing latency <10ms
- Sessions survive disconnects
- Smooth terminal rendering (no flicker)

## Gate Criteria
- [ ] All tasks complete
- [ ] All tests passing
- [ ] No code smells
- [ ] User review and acceptance

## References
- Architecture: notes/ARCHITECTURE.md (Phase 5 → Phase 1 section)
- Parent: gbe-mva

title: Define protocol and message types
description:
Define the core protocol for communication between GBE components.

- Protocol message enum definitions
- Serialization strategy (bincode vs JSON)
- Message framing specification
- ToolId and addressing scheme
- Position, Range, ViewWindow types

## Acceptance Criteria

## References
- Architecture: notes/ARCHITECTURE.md (Protocol section)

## Notes
This is foundational - other components depend on this.
notes:
Protocol design completed and documented in docs/design/protocol-v1.md.

## Key Design Decisions
- Dual channel: control (JSON) + data (binary/raw)
- Router assigns ToolId (PID+seq format) and addresses
- Proxy subprocess for tee operations (Phase 1)
- Framing controlled by capability: "raw" = Unix pipe, default = length-prefix
- Direct vs proxy routing transparent to tools

## Implementation Tasks
1. Define Rust types for ControlMessage enum
2. Define DataFrame struct for framed mode
3. Implement JSON serialization for control channel
4. Implement binary framing for data channel
5. Write unit tests for message serialization
6. Document wire format examples

See design doc for complete specification.

title: Implement gbe-proxy for data channel tee
description:
Build the proxy subprocess that enables tee functionality for data channels.

## Purpose
When multiple tools subscribe to the same source, router spawns a proxy to duplicate data streams.

## Deliverables
- Standalone binary: gbe-proxy
- Connects to upstream data socket
- Accepts multiple downstream connections
- Duplicates data frames to all subscribers
- Monitors TCP backpressure
- Sends FlowControl messages to router (control channel)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Can connect to upstream tool's data socket
- [ ] Can accept multiple downstream connections
- [ ] Correctly duplicates framed data messages
- [ ] Handles raw mode (passthrough without parsing)
- [ ] Detects write blocking (slow consumer)
- [ ] Sends control messages for backpressure events
- [ ] Clean shutdown when last subscriber disconnects
- [ ] Unit tests for tee logic
- [ ] Integration tests with mock tools

## Implementation Notes

### Startup
```bash
gbe-proxy \
  --router unix:///tmp/gbe-router.sock \
  --upstream unix:///tmp/gbe-12345-001.sock \
  --listen unix:///tmp/gbe-proxy-56789.sock \
  --mode framed|raw
```

### Behavior
- Reads from upstream (one connection)
- Writes to all downstream (multiple connections)
- On write block: sends FlowControl message via router control channel
- On upstream EOF: closes all downstream, exits
- On last downstream disconnect: cleanup (configurable: immediate vs timeout)

### Phase 1 Scope
- Subprocess implementation (simple, isolated)
- Basic tee functionality
- Backpressure monitoring (log only)

### Future Enhancements (document for later)
- In-process as router thread/task
- Kernel-level tee (splice syscall)
- Smart buffering for slow consumers
- Per-subscriber flow control

## Dependencies
- Requires: Protocol definitions (gbe-1dv.4)
- Requires: Router for control channel integration (gbe-1dv.5)

## References
- Design: docs/design/protocol-v1.md (Proxy Subprocess section)
- Architecture: notes/ARCHITECTURE.md
- Parent: gbe-1dv (Phase 1)
